context.p: Use this procedure to configure an NTP master server on the master host. Perform this procedure only if the host does not have internet access.
context.note: On VMware vSphere guests, before performing this procedure, disable time synchronization between guest and host operating systems.

step.cmd: Log in to the master host .
Create a backup of the NTP configuration file.

substep.cmd: Replace all of the lines in the file with the following lines:

stepxmp.codeblock:
# Use the local clock server 127.127.1.0 prefer fudge 127.127.1.0 stratum 10 driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift broadcastdelay 0.008
# Give localhost full access rights restrict 127.0.0.1
# Grant access to client hosts restrict ADDRESS_RANGE mask NETMASK nomodify notrap

substep.cmd: Replace ADDRESS_RANGE with the range of IPv4 network addresses that are allowed to query this NTP server.

stepxmp.p: For example, the following IP addresses are assigned to the hosts in an cluster: 203.0.113.10 203.0.113.11 203.0.113.12 203.0.113.13
For the preceding addresses, the value for ADDRESS_RANGE is 203.0.113.0.

substep.cmd: Replace NETMASK with the IPv4 network mask that corresponds with the address range.
substep.stepxmp: For example, a valid network mask for 203.0.113.0 is 255.255.255.0.

substep.cmd: Save the file and exit the editor.

step.cmd: Enable and start the NTP daemon.

substep.cmd: Configure ntpd to start when the system starts.
substep.info: Currently, an unresolved issue associated with NTP prevents ntpd from restarting correctly after a reboot, and the following commands provide a workaround to ensure that it does.
